list-item.p: Marcia Van Riper, PhD, RN, FAAN, professor at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill School of Nursing, and current president of the International Family Nursing Association, has been selected by the J. William Fulbright Foreign Scholarship Board (FSB) to receive a 2012-2013 Fulbright Scholar Grant to Ireland. She will collaborate with faculty at the Catherine McAuley School of Nursing and Midwifery, University College Cork, Ireland, in teaching, research, and publishing. She will use this opportunity to conduct a mixed-methods, cross-cultural study designed to address existing gaps in knowledge concerning how cultural scripts (cultural norms, values, and practices) and a variety of family factors (i.e., family demands, family appraisal, family resources, family problem-solving communication, family coping, and family management styles) contribute to adaptation and resilience in families of individuals with Down syndrome. Initially, the study will be conducted with families of individuals with Down syndrome in Ireland and the United States (more than 550 parents from the United States have already participated in the study). Eventually, the study will include participants from a number of different countries (e.g., Brazil, Italy, Korea, Japan, Netherlands, Portugal, and Thailand). For more information, please contact Dr. Van Riper: vanriper@email.unc.edu.

Family nursing leaders in the European Union have recently received funding for a 2-year project to collate and disseminate family nursing literature, resources, and expertise. The collaboration involves colleagues from Scotland, Portugal, Poland, Austria, Germany, Slovenia, and Romania: http://www.uws.ac.uk/schoolsdepts/hnm/family-health-nursing/index.asp. For more information about this project, contact Dr. Maria do Céu Barbieri Figueiredo: ceubarbieri@esenf.pt

Fabie Duhamel, RN, PhD, professor at University of Montreal, Quebec, Canada, has received funding from the Canadian Institutes of Health Research to bring together Family Systems Nursing colleagues from six countries (Canada, Iceland, Japan, Sweden, Thailand, the United States) to discuss a collaborative effort focused on knowledge transfer of family nursing to practice settings. Knowledge users will also participate in the planning meeting. For more information about this project, contact Dr. Fabie Duhamel: fabie.duhamel@umontreal.ca

Francine de Montigny, PhD, professor at University of Quebec at Outaouais, Canadian Research Chair in Psychosocial Family Health, and director of the Center of Research and Family Studies in Family Intervention (Quebec, Canada) has received $2.5 million of knowledge transfer funding to implement and evaluate the FATHER FRIENDLY INITIATIVE WITHIN THE FAMILY©. This 5-year project, supported by Avenir d’Enfants, aims to support nurses and their colleagues from various health and psychosocial disciplines to develop father-inclusive interventions. For more information about this project, contact Dr. Francine deMontigny: francine.demontigny@uqo.ca

Lorraine M. Wright, RN, PhD, professor emeritus at University of Calgary, was awarded an honorary doctorate from Linnaeus University, Sweden, on May 25, 2012, for her outstanding leadership in family nursing. For more information, contact Dr. Eva Benzein, Linnaeus University: eva.benzein@lnu.se

On May 19, 2012, Lorraine M. Wright, RN, PhD, Janice M. Bell, RN, PhD, and Wendy Watson Nelson, PhD, received an Innovative Contribution to Family Therapy Award from the American Family Therapy Academy in recognition for their development and dissemination of practice knowledge for families experiencing serious illness. The award was presented by Dr. Susan McDaniel. For more information, contact Dr. Lorraine Wright: lmwright@ucalgary.ca
